speaker: Neil
text: Hello. This is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I’m Neil.

speaker: Sam
text: And I’m Sam.

speaker: Neil
text: Are you feeling well, Sam? No headache or sore throat?

speaker: Sam
text: No, I feel fine thanks, Neil. Why do you ask?

speaker: Neil
text: Well, I’ve been reading some inspirational stories about the doctors and nurses fighting Covid. When I was a boy, I always dreamed of becoming a doctor.

speaker: Sam
text: Ah, I see. Have you ever been in hospital?

speaker: bedside manner
text: Yes, I have, and I remember the nurse’s bedside manner – you know, the kind and caring way that doctors and nurses treat people who are ill.

speaker: bedside manner
text: Nowadays more and more of the jobs that humans do are being carried out by machines. But I doubt that a doctor’s bedside manner could easily be replaced by a robot.

speaker: Neil
text: In this programme, we’ll be discussing whether the revolution in artificial intelligence, often shortened to ‘AI’, could replace human doctors and nurses. We’ll be asking: can you imagine a future without doctors?

speaker: Sam
text: In fact, machines are already doing some of the jobs traditionally done by doctors - scanning people’s bodies to detect skin cancer, for example.

speaker: Neil
text: Yes, that’s true, Sam, and it links to my quiz question which is about human skin. It’s a well-known fact that skin is the human body’s largest organ – but how much skin does the average adult have? Is it:

speaker: Neil
text: a) 2 square metres?,

speaker: Neil
text: b) 3 square metres? or,

speaker: Neil
text: c) 4 square metres?

speaker: Sam
text: Of course our skin gets loose as we age but I can’t believe there’s 3 square metres of it! I’ll say the answer is a) 2 square metres.

speaker: Neil
text: OK, we’ll find out if that’s correct later. Every year in the UK over 5 million people are treated for skin cancer. Catch it early and your chances of survival are increased.

speaker: Sam
text: Usually a skin specialist, or dermatologist, will examine your skin using a handheld microscope. But in 2017, a team of researchers at Stanford Medical School made an exciting announcement.

speaker: Neil
text: Here’s Oxford University researcher Daniel Susskind, telling BBC World Service programme, The Big Idea, what the medics at Stanford had invented:

speaker: frecklecancerous
text: A team of researchers at Stamford last year announced the development of a system that, if you give it a photo of a freckle it can tell you as accurately as twenty-one leading dermatologists whether or not that freckle is cancerous.

speaker: freckles
text: The Stanford medical team had invented an AI system to analyse freckles – small brown spots found on people’s skin, especially on pale skin.

speaker: cancerous
text: As it turned out the AI programme was better than human doctors at telling whether a freckle was harmless or cancerous – connected to some type of cancer.

speaker: Sam
text: So, it seems that artificial intelligence is already replacing humans when it comes to detecting cancer – and doing a better job of it.

speaker: Neil
text: But Daniel Susskind isn’t convinced. One reason is that AI systems still need humans to programme them – and as it turns out, knowing exactly how doctors detect illness remains something of a mystery.

speaker: Sam
text: Here’s Daniel Susskind again in conversation with BBC World Service programme, The Big Idea:

speaker: diagnosisrules of thumbwhere on earth
text: If you ask a doctor how it is they make a diagnosis, they might be able to point you to particularly revealing parts of a reference book or give you a few rules of thumb, but ultimately they’d struggle… they’d say again it requires things like creativity and judgment, and these things are very difficult to articulate – and so traditionally it’s been thought very hard to automate – if a human being can’t explain how they do these special things, where on earth do we begin in writing instructions for a machine to follow?

speaker: diagnosis
text: Most doctors find it difficult to explain how they make a diagnosis – their judgement about what someone’s particular sickness is, made by examining them.

speaker: rules of thumbA rule of thumb
text: Diagnosing someone’s illness is complicated but there are some rules of thumb. A rule of thumb is a practical but approximate way of doing something.

speaker: Neil
text: For example, when cooking, a good rule of thumb is two portions of water to one portion of rice.

speaker: where on earthwhere, how or what on earth
text: Exactly. And because identifying sickness is so difficult, Daniel says “where on earth do we begin writing instructions for a machine?” We use phrases like where, how or what on earth to show feelings like anger, surprise or disbelief.

speaker: how on earth
text: I might show surprise by asking Sam, ‘how on earth did you know the answer to that?’

speaker: Sam
text: Ha ha! I guess you’re talking about your quiz question, Neil? And you needn’t be so surprised – I’m naturally brainy!

speaker: Neil
text: Of course you are. In my quiz question I asked Sam how much skin there is on an adult human body.

speaker: Sam
text: And I said it was a) 2 square metres.

speaker: bedside manner
text: Which was… the correct answer! With your brains I think you’d make a good doctor, Sam, and I’m sure you’d have a good bedside manner too.

speaker: freckle
text: You mean, the kind and caring way that doctors and nurses treat their patients. OK, let’s recap the rest of the vocabulary, starting with freckle – a small brown spot on someone’s skin.

speaker: cancerous
text: Freckles are usually harmless, but some skin spots can be cancerous – connected to cancer.

speaker: diagnosis
text: A doctor’s diagnosis is their judgement about what someone’s particular sickness or disease is.

speaker: rule of thumb
text: A rule of thumb is a useful but approximate way of doing or measuring something.

speaker: where on earth..?
text: And finally, we use phrases like where on earth..? as a way to show emotions like anger, surprise or disbelief.

speaker: Neil
text: That’s all for this programme but join us for the next edition of 6 Minute English when we’ll discuss another trending topic and the related vocabulary.

speaker: Sam
text: Why on earth would you miss it? Goodbye for now!

speaker: Neil
text: Goodbye!
